text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with lemon bars that's right i
cannot believe i haven't made these yet
this is one of my favorite cookies of
all time although technically they're
closer to a pie than a cookie which is
probably why we call them bars but
nonetheless they are super simple to
make and virtually impossible to screw
up that's right I don't believe in
jinxes so let's get started by preparing
the base of our lemon bars which is a
classic shortbread cookie dough so in a
bowl I have some room temperature butter
okay don't use cold butter it's got to
be malleable to that we're going to add
some white all-purpose flour some
powdered sugar also known as
confectioner sugar I know I wish I would
decide on one name for or two it's
probably that damn confectioners Lobby
but anyway a little powdered sugar some
salt and a little bit of vanilla extract
and once that's all in there you're
going to take the back of a spatula and
or wooden spoon and simply mash that all
together so just keep rubbing and
smashing the butter against the dry
ingredients until you can't see any more
flour and it looks like this it's pretty
much going to look and feel like a
cookie dough which is not weird at all
because that's exactly what it is at
that point we're going to dump this into
a lightly oiled 8x8 baking dish so I'm
going to crumble that in kind of evenly
and then use my hand to Pat it down flat
if you want to dampen your hands a
little bit that helps but try to push it
down as evenly as you can and when
that's all pressed down nice and evenly
we're going to take a fork and we're
going to prick it except pastry chefs
don't call it pricking they call it
docking it does sound less offensive and
that's going to help this cook nice and
evenly it's also going to prevent the
dough from bubbling up and by the way if
someone walks in the kitchen it says
what's up you have to say doc okay and
once our dough has been docked we're
going to go ahead and bake this at 350
degrees for 22 minutes and at that point
you're going to take it out it should
just barely be starting to get golden
brown if we were going to eat these
cookies we'd let them go for another 10
minutes or so but we need to bake this
again with the lemon mixture so this is
just giving us a little head start so
we're going to go ahead and set that
aside while we make the lemon layer
which is even easier than the shortbread
so in a bowl I have two large eggs to
which we're going to add one extra egg
yolk to the eggs we're gonna add white
granulated sugar and a little bit of
flour and I like to give that a mix
before we add our lemon juice
I think it's a little easier to whisk
and speaking it easier to whisk please
use a regular mixing bowl at home I was
using this class one because I thought
it would photograph better and it ended
up being hard to stir and very annoying
but anyway I was stubborn and I
persisted in like 20 minutes later it
was mixed and once that is mixed you can
go ahead and add your freshly squeezed

going to add a whole bunch of lemon zest
and see right there that's why you got
to buy fresh lemons how are you going to
zest one of those little plastic lemons
you're not okay so our lemon juice and
lemon zest is in let's go ahead and mix
that very thoroughly do not let my
editing fool you I stirred that
vigorously for at least two minutes you
want to make sure it's all very very
well mixed and once you're sure it is go
ahead and pour that onto your shortbread
base do not give it the old tap a tap it
it will splash but if you want to give
it a little shake a shaker go ahead just
a small one une petite shake a shaker
and then we're going to very carefully
place that back in the center of our 350
degree oven and we're going to cook that
for exactly 25 minutes and when it comes
out it's going to look like that it will
be sat there will be no jiggling or
wiggling with that additional 25 minutes
our shortbread is going to be cooked
perfectly the lemon custard layer is
going to be set and the top will have
this very thin but very crisp kind of
sugar-coated surface and then yes the
bad news let this cool completely before
trying to cut it and then before you cut
it get yourself a nice glass a hot hot
water and when the knife gets dirty go
ahead and dip it in and clean it off
that's just good technique and if you
let it cool this will be very easy to
cut start by going all the way around
the outside and when that's done I'm
going to go ahead and cut this into 16
beautiful squares which I guess would
make this lemon squares
since bars are normally rectangular but
we're not going to get into that

give you 16 beautiful bars and you can

should get really nice cuts and by the
way in my opinion these are much better
served cold not only do they taste

and that's it the final step is usually
a nice dusting of powdered sugar and
that looks like something I want to put

and as good as they look nothing really
prepares you for that intense awesome

perfect
we contrasted against that crisp sweet

these are truly amazing simply dusted
